summary: In Walter Loeb v. Solomon Nasser, the West Africa Court of Appeal reviewed a claim for damages following the plaintiff's wrongful dismissal from a three-year engineering contract in Kumasi. The trial court awarded £249 0s. 8d., but the defendant appealed, arguing that the plaintiff’s refusal of re-employment rendered damages nominal. The appellate court upheld the finding of wrongful dismissal, emphasizing that refusal to accept re-employment is only detrimental if unreasonable, which was not established here. However, the court reversed part of the damages award, reducing it to £216 2s. 5d., after determining that the trial judge misinterpreted ledger entries that conclusively showed a £12 advance salary payment. The court also agreed to reduce the award for the wife’s passage by £20 18s. 3d., as conceded by the respondent. Costs were apportioned equally due to the partial success of the appeal.
verdict: Appeal allowed in part; damages reduced based on documentary evidence misinterpretation.
citations: Brace v. Calder 0- Others (1895 2 Q.B.D., p. 253)
rationaleHighlights: Refusal of re-employment must be unreasonable to justify only nominal damages.
Court may reverse findings based on clear misunderstanding of documentary evidence.
Plaintiff's foreign status and war conditions justified higher damages.
Ledger entries proved advance of salary, contradicting trial judge's interpretation.
Costs apportioned equally due to partial success on appeal.
